statement: The sub-layer specific communication between ACC and CA1 represents the discovery of a novel and functionally impactful piece of neurobiology.

The optogenetic manipulation experiments convincingly demonstrate that stimulation of ACC pyramidal neurons activates an interneuron population with symmetric spike waveforms, and inhibits parvalbumin interneurons and pyramidal cells in CA1sup but not CA1deep sublayer.

The proposed method to classify CA1 neurons into superficial and deep sublayers based on their sharp-wave deflection characteristics lacks validation using histology or other anatomical methods, instead relying on physiology to infer anatomical location.
The method to divide cells relative to their prediction gain fails to select for the population of significantly predicted cells relative to the shuffle.
The acceptance and robustness of defining superficial and deep CA1 neurons solely by ripple waveform is questionable, as the referenced papers use different methodological approaches.

The analysis approach pools neurons across mice and analyzes them as if independent, rather than using a hierarchical model that accounts for the interdependence of neurons recorded from the same mouse at the same time.
More discussion is needed about the v-type neurons mentioned in the research plan.
